results.title: How Jane Conquest Rang the Bell
results.brief_description: Jane’s conquest was a melodramatic magic lantern show which was hugely popular and performed with reading of poem by Dr Croft who rewrote and adapted the poem by James Milne. It featured an early form of special effects, by use of a second magic lantern slide projected over the first with a biunial magic lantern. This is considered to be an early form of superimpostion, which became a common effect in photography and cinematography. It consisted of 17 slides to be used on a biunial magic lantern, the 17th slide being of an angel to be superimposed over slide 4 and 16 to suggest the presence of an angel.
results.description: Jane’s conquest was a melodramatic magic lantern show which was hugely popular and performed with reading of poem by Dr Croft who rewrote and adapted the poem by James Milne. results.title: How its surface changes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Understanding Our Earth”.
Explains the slow but constant changes in the surface of the earth by showing the erosive effects of water and wind upon a recently excavated mound of raw earth. Includes scenes of the eruption of the Paracutin Volcano, the Grand Canyon of the Colorado River, and a rocky mountainside, pointing out the geologic evidence of forces which continue to build up and wear away the surface of the earth.

results.title: How it works
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Open hearth furnace series”.
An explanation of how the furnace is constructed to withstand the very high temperatures needed to make steel. The system of regeneration by which gas and air are heated before being burned in the furnace is also illustrated.

results.title: How insects help us
results.brief_description: A junior social studies film. Develops four ideas about insects: that all are worth observing and learning about; some are helpful; others harmful; and some are beautiful. Behaviour of wasps, ants, bees, flies, grasshoppers and others is studied.

results.title: How green plants make and use food. - Rev. ed.
results.brief_description: Uses clear animation and time-lapse microphotography to show how materials reach the leaves of a plant from the roots and how light supplies the energy for the manufacture of sugar. Clarifies the difference between food and raw materials and between photosynthesis and cellular respiration. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: How good is a 'good guy'?
results.creator_credit: Jack Denove, Leon S. Gold and Roundtable Productions
results.brief_description: Indicates the many hidden problems caused when supervisors are more concerned with their own needs than with the needs of their men and their company.

results.title: How fibres are spun
results.brief_description: Shows methods of spinning that were practised before the Industrial Revolution, and so elucidates the basic operations of the mechanical spindle. Shows the opening out and carding of wool and cotton by hand.

results.title: How far how soon? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Eurfron Gwynne Jones and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Children Growing Up”.
This program covers the range and pattern of normal physical development and, where possible, relates this to the emotional changes which occur. However, children of the same chronological age may vary enormously in their true maturity. This has implications for school assessment, relationships and the early choice of future careers.

results.title: How fair is the jury system?
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, George Cass and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: An audience of students questions a prominent barrister on the fairness of the jury system. The program considers such issues as choosing a jury, eligibility of jurors and alternatives or reforms of the jury sustem.

results.title: How electricity is produced
results.creator_credit: Thomas Stanton, Pat Dowling and Pat Dowling Pictures
results.brief_description: Explains the three ways in which electricity is produced. Depicts Faraday discovering the principle of an induced current, and demonstrates with a small magneto-generator the principle of current electricity.
